newsitem.title: FINLAND: IHALAINEN SAYS BROAD '98 PAY DEAL DIFFICULT - RADIO.
newsitem.headline: IHALAINEN SAYS BROAD '98 PAY DEAL DIFFICULT - RADIO.

text.p: Lauri Ihalainen, chairman of the Central Organisation of Finnish Trade Unions (SAK), said on Friday it would probably be more difficult to reach a new broad centralised pay deal from February 1998 than it had been two years ago, Finnish radio news reported.

Ihalainen told an SAK council meeting that there were now more branch-specific issues to deal with between unions and employers, and that some branches felt a need to get their share of corporate profits, the radio said.
Ihalainen also said the nominal pay rise element should be bigger than the tax cut element in next incomes settlement.
"We must be prepared also for the alternative that this time the conditions will not exist for a broad incomes settlement," Finnish news agency STT quoted Ihalainen as saying.
But he noted that a majority of SAK member unions have said that their targets would best be served by a centralised deal.
SAK's May 23-24 council meeting is scheduled to make a preliminary decision on the organisation's targets for the next incomes settlement from February 1998, STT said.

Ihalainen said a new two-year deal after the 1996-97 agreement would be justified from the point of view that pay talks would then not clash with the campaign for the March 1999 general election, STT said.
Working hours should be reduced, but unions should not set unrealistic targets in this field, STT quoted Ihalainen as saying.
